children.name: Part 1: General Topography of the Neck

fields:
Prevertebral flexor musculature is composed of which muscles? What are their immediate anterior and posterior relations?

{{c1::
Rectus capitis anterior
Rectus capitis lateralis
Longus capitis
Longus colli
Scalene anterior
Scalene medius
Scalene posterior
Levator scapulae

Anteriorly, the prevertebral fascia
Posteriorly, the vertebral column
}}

What vertebral level is the hard palate?

{{c1::C1 (anterior arch of atlas)}}

What vertebral level is lower border of mandible?

{{c1::Between C2 and C3}}

What marks the end of the pharynx? What vertebral level is this?

{{c1::Cricoid cartilage. C6.}}

What compartment lies anterior to the prevertebral fascia? Roughly what lies within this compartment?

{{c1::The viscera of the neck. Pharynx, oesophagus, larynx, trachea and carotid sheaths on either side of the pharynx.}}

What structure defines the upper limit of the anterior neck?

{{c1::Mylohyoid muscles}}
The thyroid gland lies {{c1::beneath::beneath/above}} the strap muscles (that connect hyoid and larynx to sternum and scapula) and is enclosed in {{c1::pretracheal}} fascia.
The cervical sympathetic trunk lies {{c1::behind::in front of/lateral to/medial to/behind}} the carotid sheath.

Which cranial nerves emerge into the neck?

{{c1::9th, 10th, 11th, 12th.}}

What are the four components of deep cervical fascia?

{{c1::
The investing layer
The pretracheal fascia
Prevertebral fascia
Carotid sheath
}}

Which muscles are contained in the investing layer of the deep cervical fascia?

{{c1::Trapezius and sternocleidomastoid muscles.}}

What are the border attachments of the investing layer of the deep cervical fascia? (Posteriorly, anteriorly, superiorly, inferiorly)

{{c1::
Posteriorly: ligamentum nuchae
Anteriorly: Hyoid bone
Superiorly (from backwards to forwards): External occipital protuberance and superior nuchal line, mastoid process, lower border of mandible (chin to angle)
Inferiorly (from backwards to forwards): spine and acromial process of scapula, upper surface of clavicle, suprasternal notch of manubrium
}}
Between the angle of the mandible and the tip of the mastoid process, the investing layer splits to form {{c1::a capsule for the parotid gland}}.
The superficial part of the capsule for the parotid gland is attached above to {{c1::the zygomatic arch}}, is thick and forms the {{c1::parotid}} fascia.
The deep part of the capsule for the parotid gland is thickened as the {{c1::stylomandibular}} ligament.
A thickening of the capsule for the parotid gland between the angle of the mandible and the anterior border of sternocleidomastoid has been described as the {{c1::mandibulostylohyoid}} ligament.
It can be traced from the angle to the lower end of the stylohyoid ligament.

Describe the form of the investing layer surrounding middle third of clavicle.

{{c1::
The investing layer of the deep cervical fascia split above the middle third of the clavicle (between SCM and trapezius) and attach to form the supraclavicular space. The deeper layer splits again (before attaching to clavicle) to encase the inferior belly of the omohyoid, forming a fascial sling which binds the muscle down to the clavicle. These two layers then continue inferior to the clavicle as the clavipectoral fascia that encloses the subclavius muscle. 

The two layers of investing layer are pierced by external jugular vein supraclavicularly.
}}

Describe the suprasternal space. What does in this space?

{{c1::
Also called the space of Burns.
In the interval between sternocleidomastoids, the investing layer splits slightly above the clavicle and jugular notch, the layers attaching to the anterior and posterior borders of the jugular notch, enclosing between them the suprasternal space. 

In this space, the anterior jugular veins angle laterally to pass behind the sternocleidomastoids. The veins are often joined in this space by an anastomatic arch. There is also the sternal heads of the SCM, areolar tissue and sometimes lymph glands.
}}

As what point does external jugular vein pierce the investing layer?

{{c1::Through the supraclavicular space, middle third of the clavicle.}}

What are the upper and lower limits of the prevertebral fascia?

{{c1::From base of skull infront of longus capitis and rectus capitis lateralis downwards to the lower limit of longus colli muscle (body of T3 vertebra).}}

What is the relation of the posterior triangle to the prevertebral fascia?

{{c1::The prevertebral fascia covers the muscles that floor the posterior triangle (scalene anterior and medius, levator scapulae, splenius capitis).}}

What is the relation of cervical nerve roots to the prevertebral fascia?

{{c1::Since the fascia crosses in front of the anterior tubercles of the cervical transverse processes, all the cervical nerve roots (and thus the cervical plexus and trunks of the brachial plexus) lie deep to it.}}

What is the relation of the accessory nerve to the prevertebral fascia?

{{c1::The accessory nerve lies superficial to the prevertebral fascia.}}
The {{c1::third::first/second/third}} part of the subclavian artery lies {{c2::deep::superficial/deep}} to the prevertebral fascia in the floor of the posterior triangle.

Which fascial layer is the axillary sheath continuous with?

{{c1::The prevertebral fascia which prolongs over the artery as it goes below the clavicle.}}
A part of the subclavian {{c1::artery}} lies deep to the prevertebral fascia while the subclavian {{c1::vein}} lies anteriorly in the loose areolar tissue.
This is to allow the vein to dilate freely during times of increased venous return.

What are the cutaneous branches of the cervical plexus and what are their relations to the prevertebral fascia?

{{c1::
Lesser occipital nerve
Greater auricular nerve
Transverse cervical nerve
Supraclavicular nerve

They pierce the preverterbral fascia.
}}

What are the two components of the pretracheal fascia and what do they ensheath?

{{c1::
Cervical layer
- Ensheathes cervical viscera including the larynx/trachea, pharynx/esophagus, thyroid and parathyroid glands
Muscular layer
- Ensheathes the infrahyoid muscles
}}

What are the limits of the pretracheal fascia?

{{c1::
Superiorly attaches to the hyoid bone
Superiolaterally, the oblique line of the thyroid cartilage (note these upper limits dictated by strap muscle attachment)
Inferiorly the fibrous pericardium
}}

Describe the fibrous coverings of the thyroid gland and its attachment posteriorly

{{c1::The thyroid gland is covered by a thin fibrous capsule, which has an inner and an outer layer. The inner layer extrudes into the gland and forms the septae that divides the thyroid tissue into microscopic lobules. The outer layer is continuous with the pretracheal fascia, attaching the gland to the cricoid and thyroid cartilages via a thickening of the fascia to form the posterior suspensory ligament of thyroid gland, also known as Berry's ligament. This causes the thyroid to move up and down with the movement of these cartilages when swallowing occurs.}}

When the thyroid gland grows, which direction does it extend? Why is that?

{{c1::The upper limit of the pretracheal fascia is the attachments of the infrahyoid  muscles. Hence, the thyroid gland is particularly limited by the attachment of the sternothyroid on the oblique line of the thyroid cartilage. Meanwhile, there are no limitations to expansion inferiorly, leading to retrosternal goitre in severe cases.}}

Describe the relation between the pretracheal fascia with the carotid sheath.

{{c1::In front of the lower part of the sheath is firmly attached the deep surface of the sternocleidomastoid and along this the lateral aspect of the pretracheal fascia blends with the front  of the carotid sheath.}}

Inferiorly, the pretracheal fascia passes {{c1::behind::in front of/behind}} the brachiocephalic veins to blend with the adventitia of {{c1::the arch of the aorta and the fibrous pericardium::two structures}}.

Where is the carotid sheath thinnest?

{{c1::Over the internal jugular vein}}
As to be expected as the vein must be free to dilate during increased venous return.

What are the contents of the carotid sheath and the position of each within the sheath?

{{c1::
Common + internal carotid artery (medial)
Internal jugular vein (lateral)
Vagus nerve (posteriorly between the two vessels)
Deep cervical lymph nodes
Ansa cervicalis (embedded in the anterior wall of sheath over IJV)
}}

In which fascial layer is the ansa cervicalis embedded?

{{c1::The anterior aspect of the carotid sheath}}

Describe the the space between the carotid sheath and the prevertebral fascia. What important structures is here?

{{c1::In this space, there is a minimum of loose areolar tissue (not enough to limit the spread of infection) and the cervical sympathetic trunk lies here, attached to the front of the prevertebral fascia.}}

What are 'tissue spaces' and what are the four most clinically important tissue spaces?

{{c1::
Potential spaces with loose connective tissue which can become expanded when invaded by infection.

The 4 most important ones are prevertebral, retropharyngeal, parapharyngeal and submandibular.
}}

Describe the prevertebral space. How can fluid escape this space?

{{c1::The prevertebral space is behind the prevertebral fascia. Extending from base of skull all the way down to lower limit of longus colli (body of T3). The only escape can be made by a perforation in the fascia.}}

Describe the retropharyngeal space. What is the danger space? What is the retrovisceral space?

{{c1::
The TRUE retropharyngeal space is bound anteriorly by the buccopharyngeal fascia on the outer surface of the pharynx and posteriorly by the alar fascia. Its superior limit is the clivus and the inferior limit is the superior medistinum, where alar fascia fuses with the buccopharyngeal fascia anywhere from C6 - T4. The space is divided into two compartments (spaces of Gillette) by a central fibrous raphe. Each compartment contains retropharyngeal nodes which disappear by the age of 3-4.

Behind the retropharyngeal space, between the alar fascia and the prevertebral fascia exists the danger space which extends down lower to the level of the diaphragm (and is continous with posterior mediastinum).

The alar fascia between them is very thin and can easily cross-contaminate due to rupture of abscesses.

Terminology isn't unified. Most say that retrovisceral = retropharyngeal + danger space. Some say retrovisceral is continuous superiorly with the retropharyngeal space. Some discard retrovisceral altogether.
}}

Infections in the retropharyngeal space may:

{{c1::
- Pass behind the carotid sheath into the posterior triangle
- Form an abscess and rupture into the danger space, leading into the mediastinum.
- Communicate laterally with the parapharyngeal space
}}

Describe the parapharyngeal space. What are its compartments and what is contained there?

{{c1::
The parapharyngeal space is a pyramidal space with its base at the base of skull and the apex at the hyoid bone.

It is bound medially by the buccopharyngeal mucosa, laterally by the  medial pterygoid muscle and parotid sheath, anteriorly by the pterygomandibular raphe and posteriorly by the prevertebral fascia (posterolateral) and retropharyngeal space (posteromedial).

It is split into an pre-styloid and post-styloid compartment by the stylopharyngeal fascia. Some sources only recognise pre-styloid compartment as true parapharyngeal space, while calling post-styloid compartment carotid space.

Nevertheless, The post-styloid compartment contains important vessels, including but not limited to CN IX, X, XI, internal carotid artery, internal jugular vein.
}}

The parapharyngeal space is continuous with the retropharyngeal space {{c1::posteriorly::anteriorly/posteriorly/medially/laterally}} and the submandibular space {{c1::anteriorly::anteriorly/posteriorly/medially/laterally}}.

Describe the submandibular space. 

{{c1::
The submandibular space extends above the investing layer of fascia between the hyoid and mandible. 

Superior border: mucous membrane of the floor of mouth. 
Inferiorly (and laterally): skin, superficial fascia, platysma muscle and investing layer Anterior( and laterally) : body of the mandible
Posteriorly: hyoid bone
Medially (on each side): anterior belly of digastric

It is split into sublingual and submylohyoid compartments by the mylohyoid muscle. Some sources don't consider the sublingual space part of the submandibular space (while Last's does). The submandibular gland hooks around the posterior border of the muscle.
}}
{{c1::Ludwig's angina}} is {{c2::an infection of the submandibular space}}.

What are the borders of the posterior triangle?

{{c1::The posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid, anterior border of trapezius and the clavicle.}}

What are the borders of the anterior triangle?

{{c1::The anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid, lower border of the mandible and the midline.}}

What are the subdivisions of the anterior triangle of the neck? What are their respective borders?

{{c1::
Submental triangle
- Anterior belly of digastric
- Midline
- Hyoid
Digastric triangle
- Mandible
- Anterior belly of digastric
- Posterior belly of digastric
Carotid triangle
- Sternocleidomastoid
- Posterior belly of digastric
- Superior belly of omohyoid
Muscular triangle
- Superior belly of omohyoid
- Sternocleidomastoid
- Midline (hyoid to jugular notch)
}}
The sternocleidomastoid muscle originates from manubrium and clavicle: that from the manubrium is a {{c1::rounded tendon::form}} while that from the clavicle is a {{c1::thick fleshy mass::form}}.

What is the most commonly used landmark for CVC insertion?

{{c1::At the triangular interval between the medial and lateral origins of sternocleidomastoid, at the lower end of the internal jugular vein.}}

What is the insertion of the sternocleidomastoid?

{{c1::Curved line extending from the tip of the mastoid process to the superior nuchal line of the occipital bone.}}

Describe the 4 components of the sternocleidomastoid muscle and their relation to each other. What is the surgical relevance of this?

{{c1::
The SCM has - in a sense - two origins (sterno-, cleido-) and two insertions (-mastoid, -occipitalis). That makes 2x2=4 muscles!

The sternomastoid and sterno-occipitalis are intimately blended. Cleido-occipitalis inserts into the superior nuchal line medial to and in line with sternooccipitalis. The three aforementioned form a continuous sheet on the surface of the muscle. The remaining fibres (cleidomastoid) lie deep to these. Between these two parts, the accessory nerve enters the muscle and runs down within it to emerge into the posterior triangle about halfway down the posterior border of the muscle.
}}
Cannot find an image of muscular components online, but clinical importance with locating accessory nerve, particularly during selective neck dissections when delineating 2a and 2b nodal levels.

The sternocleidomastoid is drawn forward in a gentle convexity when the head is rotated. Why is that?

{{c1::The SCM is enclosed within a sheath of investing layer of deep cervical fascia which is attached anteriorly to the hyoid bone.}}

What structures lie deep to the sternocleidomastoid?

{{c1::
Deep to the upper half lies the cervical plexus
Deep to the lower part lies the common carotid artery and carotid sheath overlying anterior scalene.
}}

What is the blood supply of the sternocleidomastoid?

{{c1::Occipital and superior thyroid arteries}}

What is the nerve supply of the sternocleidomastoid muscle?

{{c1::Spinal part of the accessory nerve, C1-6 but mostly C2 and C3, from a branch which leaves it proximal to its point of entry into the muscle.}}
The anterior horn cells of the segments supplying sternocleidomastoid are innervated by {{c1::ipsilateral::ipsilateral/contralateral}} cerebral cortex.

Meanwhile, those supplying the trapezius receive the usual contralateral innervation.
The reason is that when, for example, the left upper limb muscles (including trapezius) are being used and the head is turned to that side to see what is going on, it is the right sternocleidomastoid that is turning the head to the left; the same (right) cortex controls all the muscles.

What is the action of the sternocleidomastoid?

{{c1::Contraction of one muscle produces the 'wry neck' position where the head rotates contralateral to the muscle, the ear approaches the tip of the shoulder.}}

How is simple rotation of the head achieved? 


{{c1::Concurrent action of the sternocleidomastoid as well as opposite abducting muscles (such as scalenus medius and semispinalis cervicis) causes the neck to be held vertical, achieving simple (but not so simple) rotation of the head.}}

What is the principle rotator of the lateral atlantoaxial joint?

{{c1::Sternocleidomastoid.}}

Sternocleidomastoid achieves the same action as which muscle on the opposite side?

{{c1::Splenius capitis.}}

What happens when both sternocleidomastoids contract simultaneously?

{{c1::When head in normal position, there is head protraction. That is, the face moves forwards while keeping head vertical and maintaining horizontal gaze (Egyptian dance thing).}}

What are the muscles that make up the floor of the posterior triangle?

{{c1::
From above downwards:
Semispinalis capitis
Splenius capitis
Levator scapulae
Scalene posterior
Scale medius
Scale anterior (may or may not be present)
First digitation of the serratus anterior (especially if shoulder depressed)
}}

Which structures are pinned between the prevertebral fascia and the lower parts of the scales and levator scapulae?

{{c1::
Subclavian artery
Three trunks of the brachial plexus
Loops of the cervical plexus
}}

What are the structures pass through the very apex of the posterior triangle?

{{c1::The occipital artery and greater occipital nerve passing up to the scalp.}}

What are the main lymph node groups in the posterior triangle?

{{c1::
2-3 occipital lymph nodes lie at the apex, enlarged in scalp infections and rubella
Numerous supraclavicular nodes above the clavicle
}}

Describe the path of the accessory nerve from its emergence from sternocleidomastoid.

{{c1::The accessory nerve emerges halfway down the posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid and travels vertically down over the levator scapulae and ends within the fascia of the roof of the triangle (investing layer) before disappearing beneath the anterior border of trapezius 5cm above the clavicle.}}

What are the surface markings of accessory nerve?

{{c1::From palpating the transverse process of the atlas (in front of mastoid process) to a point on the anterior border of trapezius 5cm above the clavicle.}}
The cutaneous branches of the cervical plexus pierce the investing fascia at {{c1::the posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid::landmark}}.
Cervical branches (C3 & C4) to trapezius pass across the fascial {{c1::floor::floor/roof}} of the triangle.
The pulsation of the subclavian artery can be felt by pressing downwards {{c1::behind the clavicle at the lateral border of the sternocleidomastoid::surface landmark}}.

Apart from the subclavian artery, what are the other arteries in the posterior triangle? Where are they situated in the triangle?

{{c1::
Occipital (from external carotid): at the apex
Transverse cervial (from thyrocervical): lower part of triangle just above clavicle
Suprascapular (from thyrocervical): lower part of triangle just above clavicle
}}
The retromandibular vein is the union of {{c1::superficial temporal vein}} and {{c1::maxillary vein.}}

The common facial vein is the union of {{c1::the anterior branch of retromandibular vein}} and {{c1::the anterior facial vein}}. The common facial vein eventually drains into {{c1::the internal jugular vein}}.
The external jugular vein is the union of {{c1::the posterior branch of the retromandibular vein}} and {{c1::the posterior auricular vein}}. It eventually drains into {{c1::the subclavian vein}}.

Which vein(s) pass(es) through the posterior triangle?

{{c1::The terminal part of the external jugular vein slips into the anterior corner of the triangle on its way to the subclavian.}}

Describe the path of the transverse cervical artery in the posterior triangle.

{{c1::The transverse cervical artery divides at the anterior border of levator scapulae, the ascending branch running up the muscle, the descending branch running down deep to it, in company with the dorsal scapular nerve.}}

What is the cervical plexus composed of?

{{c1::The cervical plexus is formed by simple loops between anterior rami of the upper four cervical nerves after each has received a grey ramus from the superior cervical ganglion. Most sources include C5 as it contrinutes the formation of the phrenic nerve.}}
Majority of the cervical plexus {{c1::does not actually lie::lies/does not lie}} in the posterior triangle. It is covered by the {{c1::upper part of the sternocleidomastoid muscle}}.

What are the branches of the cervical plexus? What are their respective nerve root contributions?

{{c1::
The branches can be divided into muscular or cutaneous branches.

Muscular branches
- A loop from C1 traveling with the hypoglossal nerve, before giving off the superior root of the ansa cervicalis (descendens hypoglossi). The rest of the fibres keep following hypoglossal and suppy thyrohyoid and geniohyoid.
- Branches from C2 & C3 to sternocleidomastoid, and branches from C3 & C4 to trapezius. 
- Inferior root of the ansa cervicalis(descendens cervicalis) formed by C2 & C3. 
-  Phrenic nerve formed mainly from C3, C4, C5 but C4 being the most important.
Cutaneous branches
- Lesser occipital nerve (C2)
- Greater auricular nerve (C2, C3, mostly 2)
- Transverse cervical nerve (C2, C3)
- Supraclavicular nerve (C3, C4 but mostly 4)
}}

Phrenic nerve runs down vertically over the obliquity of the {{c1::scalenus anterior}} muscle, passing from lateral to medial border, {{c1::beneath::above/beneath}} the prevertebral fascia, lateral to the {{c1::ascending cervical branch of the inferior thyroid}} artery. It passes {{c1::behind::in front of/behind} the subclavian vein into the mediastinum.

What is accessory phrenic nerve?

{{c1::An anatomic variant where the main phrenic nerve is joined by another small tributary which can originate from the ansa cervicalis or the nerve to subclavius. It occurs in a third of patients.}}

Does phrenic nerve always pass behind the subclavian vein?

{{c1::Most of the time. However, it is not unusual for it pass anteriorly or even penetrate the vein. This is understood by recalling that the subclavian vein is formed by a coalescence of rich venous plexus in the embryo.}}

What is the course and area of supply of lesser occipital nerve?

{{c1::The lesser occipital nerve hooks around the accessory nerve and ascends along the posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid to supply the posterior part of the neck up to superior nuchal line and behind the auricle.}}

What is the path and area of supply of the greater auricular nerve?

{{c1::
The large trunk passes vertically upwards over the sternocleidomastoid. It supplies:
- Skin over the angle of the mandible
- Parotid gland and parotid fascia (deep layer too)
- Skin of the entire medial surface of the auricle 
- Lower part of the lateral auricle below the external acoustic meatus (i.e. ear lobe).
- Skin over mastoid region
}}

The transverse cervical nerve consists of contributions from {{c1::C2 & C3}}, emerges as a single trunk behind the posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid and quickly breaks up into a number of slender twigs that innervate {{c1::the skin in the midline of the neck from chin to sternum.}}

What is the nerve root contributions of the supraclavicular nerve?

{{c1:: C3 + 4 but mostly C4}}

Describe the branches of the supraclavicular nerve and what they supply respectively.

{{c1::
Divides into three branches (groups): medial, intermediate and lateral
- Medial group supplies skin supplies skin as far down as the sternal angle and sternoclavicular joint
- Intermediate group passes anterior to clavicle and supplies as far down as the anterior axial line
- Lateral group pass across acromion to the skin halfway down the deltoid muscle AND over posterior aspect of the shoulder to supply skin as far down as spine of the scapula.
}}

What is an axial line?

{{c1::The axial line is the line between two adjacent dermatomes that are not represented by immediately adjacent spinal levels. }}

Although dermatomes are shown to be discrete segments on dermatomal maps (like in the image opposite), they are in fact not; adjacent dermatomes overlap with one another. This is one of the reasons for the variety of different dermatomal maps proposed. <u style="">However, at axial lines, adjacent dermatomes do not overlap.</u>

Which cervical nerve does not supply any skin?

{{c1::C1}}
The greater occipital nerve is a branch of the {{c1::C2 dorsal ramus}}
The third occipital nerve (or least occipital nerve) is a branch of the {{c1::C3 dorsal ramus}}. It lies {{c1::medial::medial/lateral}} to the greater occipital nerve.

Which nerves supply sensory fibres for the back of the neck?

{{c1::
Greater occipital nerve (posterior ramus of C2)
Third occipital nerve (posterior ramus of C3)
}}

Describe the area of C2 dermatome.

{{c1::Most of the posterior part of the neck extending into the occipital region of the scalp and forwards to the auricle and the face over angle of mandible.}}

Describe the area of C3 dermatome.

{{c1::C3 supplies the cylindrical part of the neck (collar or choker area).}}

Describe the C4 dermatome.

{{c1::C4 extends over the clavicular region across the top of the shoulder and down to the scapular spine.}}

Regarding the suprahyoid muscles:

{{c1::Mylohyoid}} from each side unite to form the floor of the mouth. {{c1::Digastrics and stylohyoids::Which muscle(s)}} is/are superficial to them and {{c1::geniohyoid::Which muscle(s)}} deep to them.
These are commonly known as the strap muscles due to their flat shape.

The infrahyoid strap muscles are in the same plane of the body wall musculature as what other muscle of the abdominal wall?

{{c1::Rectus abdominis.}}

Another strange yet interesting Last's 'segue'

One should picture the rectus sheet as extending from chin to pubic symphysis, supplied segmentally from C1 to T12 spinal nerve but interrupted by intervention from the thoracic cage. There are sometimes remnants of the longitudinal strip sometimes overlying the pectoralis major, an anatomical anomaly called rectus sternalis.

Digastric muscle

Origins
{{c1::
Posterior belly - digastric notch on medial surface of mastoid process
Anterior belly - digastric fossa on inner surface of mandible
}}
Insertion
{{c2::- Both triangle bellies taper down to an intermediate tendon which is held beneath a fibous sling attached to the lesser horn of the hyoid bone.}}
Nerve supply
{{c3::
- Posterior belly supplied by facial nerve (arising between stylomastoid foramen and parotid gland)
- Anterior belly supplie by nerve to mylohyoid (V3)
}}
Action
{{c4::
- Depress and retract the chin
- Assist the lateral pterygoid in opening the mouth
}}

What is the relation of the digastric to the stylohyoid?

{{c1::The stylohyoid is perforated by the intermediate tendon of the digastric near its insertion onto the greater cornu of the hyoid. This bears no functional significance whatsoever.}}

What is the relation of the digastric muscle to mylohyoid?

{{c1::The anterior belly of the digastric lies on the inferior surface of mylohyoid.}}

Stylohyoid

Origin
{{c1::
- Back of the styloid process, high up near the base of skull
- Slopes down along upper border of posterior belly
}}
Insertion
{{c2::
- Base of greater horn of the hyoid bone
- Lower end divides to embrace the digastric intermediate tendon then inserts by two slips 
}}
Nerve supply
{{c3::- Facial nerve branch, by a branch arising with nerve to posterior belly}}
Action
{{c4::- Retract and elevate the hyoid bone when swallowing}}

Mylohyoid

Origin
{{c1::- Mylohyoid line of each respective side, extending back as far as third molar}}
Insertion
{{c2::
- Two muscles slope downwards towards each other
- Posterior quarter of each inserts onto anterior surface of the body of hyoid
- Anterior three-quarters interdigitate in a midline raphe which extends from chin to hyoid
}}
Nerve supply
{{c3::- Its own nerve, a branch of the inferior alveolar nerve (V3) which arises just before the parents nerve enters the mandibular foramen.}}
Action
{{c4::
- Forms a thin, mobile but stable floor of mouth and supports the weight and thrust of the tongue
- Acts during swallowing or tongue protrusion to elevate the floor of mouth, elevating tongue and hyoid bone
}}

Geniohyoid 

Origin
{{c1::- Inferior mental spine (genial tubercle)}}
Insertion
{{c2::
- Upper border of body of hyoid bone
- Two muscles lie side by side between mylohyoid and base of tongue (genioglossus)
}}
Nerve supply
{{c3::- C1 via hypoglossal nerve}}
Action
{{c4::
- Protracts and elevates the hyoid bone in swallowing
- If hyoid is fixed, depresses the mandible
}}

Sternohyoid

Origin
{{c1::- Back of sternoclavicular joint and adjoining parts of manubrium and clavicle}}
Insertion
{{c2::
- Lower border of hyoid bone
- Two muscles lie edge to edge at hyoid bone but diverge from each other below
- The Adam's apple projects through the space between them.
}}
Nerve supply
{{c3::
- Ansa cervicalis (C1, C2, C3) branch entering at the lower end of the muscle and running up
- Supplied segmentally (C1-3 from above down)
}}

Omohyoid 

Origin
{{c1::
Superior belly: intermediate tendon 
Inferior belly: transverse scapular ligament and little of upper border of scapula
}}
Insertion
{{c2::
Superior belly: lateral part of inferior border of hyoid bone. At this attachment, lies edge to edge with sternohyoid. However, as it descends it diverges from it
Inferior belly: intermediate tendon
}}
Nerve supply
{{c3::- Ansa cervicalis (C1, C2, C3 from above down)}}

As it descends from its hyoid attachment, the omohyoid divulges from the sternohyoid. It then passes {{c1::beneath::over/beneath}} the sternocleidomastoid and comes to lie {{c1::over::over/beneath}} the carotid sheath.

Which part of the omohyoid overlies the internal jugular vein?

{{c1::The flat tendinous portion.}}

The intermediate tendon and supraclavicular portion of the omohyoid are bound down to the clavicle in a fascial sling derived from {{c1::the deep layer of the investing layer of deep cervical fascia.}}

Describe the development of the omohyoid from fetus to adult.

{{c1::In the fetus, the omohyoid starts off attached to the medial end of the clavicle, a longitudinal strip of muscle like the rest of the infrahyoid musculature. However, it migrates along the clavicle during development and reaches its adult attachment to the scapula.}}

## (origin and insertion debacle) Thyrohyoid

Origin
{{c1::- Oblique line of thyroid cartilage, end to end with sternothyroid}}
Insertion
{{c2::- Greater horn of hyoid bone}}
Nerve supply
{{c3::- C1 via hypoglossal}}

N.B. Last's says that the oblique line of thyroid is the INSERTION. However, common sense and etymology suggests that the prefix thyro- would indicate origin. I will investigate into this and possibly change this note. In fact, this note applies to the other infrahyoid muscles.

Sternothyroid

Origin
{{c1::
- Posterior surface of manubrium + extends laterally from the manubrium to the first costal cartilage.
- Origin lower than sternohyoid, below the sternoclavicular joint so that there is no attachment to the clavicle at all.
}}
Insertion
{{c2::- Oblique line of thyroid cartilage}}
Nerve supply
{{c3::- Ansa cervicalis (C2 and C3 only)}}

How does the origin of the sternothyroid compare to that of sternohyoid?

{{c1::Sternothyroid origin on posterior manubrium is lower than sternohyoid}}

Infrahyoid muscles are all {{c1::depressors::elevators/depressors}} of the larynx. Depression of the larynx {{c1::increases::increases/decreases}} the volume of the resonating chambers during phonation and thus affects quality of voice.

What are the elevators of the larynx?

{{c1::
Mylohyoid
Palatopharyngeus
Stylopharyngeus
Salpingopharyngeus
Inferior constrictor
}}

Which muscle(s) prevent the ascent of the hyoid when digastric is in action?

{{c1::The infrahyoid muscles}}
When the head is rotated to one side, the {{c1::contralateral::ipsilateral/contralateral}} omohyoid is straightened and can exert more direct downward force on the hyoid bone.
The isthmus of the thyroid gland overlies {{c1::the second, third and fourth::which}} tracheal ring(s).

Classically, what is the shape of each thyroid lateral lobe? How many surfaces does each lateral lobe have?

{{c1::Each lateral lobe is pear-shaped with narrow upper pole and broader lower pole. On transverse sections, it has an approximately triangular cross-section with latera, medial and posterior surfaces.}}
The lateral (superficial) surface of the thyroid gland is under the cover of {{c1::sternothyroid and sternohyoid::which muscles}}.
The upper pole is tucked away beneath the upper end of the sternothyroid, which hence limits extension of an enlarging lobe.

The medial surface of the thyroid gland lies against the lateral side of the larynx and upper trachea, the lower pole extending along the side of the trachea as low as the {{c1::sixth::which}} tracheal ring.

What are the medial muscular relations to the medial surface of the thyroid gland?

{{c1::
Cricothyroid muscles of the larynx
Inferior constrictor muscles of pharynx
}}

What are the relations of the posterior surface of the thyroid gland?

{{c1::The posterior surface overlaps the medial part of the carotid sheath (the part containing the carotid artery). The parathyroid gland usually lies in contact with this surface between it and the fascial sheath.}}
The inferior thyroid artery arches behind the lower pole of the thyroid gland at the level of {{c1::C6}}.

What is the relation of recurrent laryngeal nerve to the inferior thyroid artery? How does this differ between left and right RLN?

{{c1::The left RLN is more likely to lie behind the inferior thyroid artery than in front. The right RLN is equal chance in front of or behind the inferior thyroid artery. They can both travel between branches of the artery.}}

The way I like to rationalise this difference is since the RLN loops from lower down on the left, it is given more chance to go behind the inferior thyroid artery, which originates as thyrocervical trunk from the subclavian artery.

The recurrent laryngeal is {{c1::behind::in front of/behind}} the pretracheal fascia, {{c1::behind::in front of/behind}} the cricothyroid joint and passes upwards under the cover of {{c1::inferior constrictor.::which muscle}}

At the level of {{c1::the upper border of the isthmus::landmark}} the recurrent laryngeal nerve often divides into two. The anterior (larger), branch is the {{c1::motor branch to the laryngeal muscles::motor/sensory/mixed}}, and the posterior branch is {{c1::sensory only::motor/sensory/mixed}}.

The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (the external laryngeal nerve) courses a millimetre or two {{c1::behind::in front of/behind}} the superior thyroid artery, passing {{c1::medial::anteriorly/medial/lateral}} to the upper lobe of the thyroid. It supplies the {{c1::cricothyroid muscle::muscle}}.
The anastamosis between the two superior thyroid arteries runs across the {{c1::upper border of the isthmus::landmark}}
Tributaries of the {{c1::inferior thyroid}} veins emerge from the lower border of the isthmus.

What is the pyramidal lobe of the thyroid?

{{c1::It is a small portion of gland substance that projects upwards from the isthmus generally to the left of midline. Embryologically, it represents the development of glandular tissue fro the caudal end of the thyroglossal duct.}}

Aside from being attached to the isthmus, what else is the pyramidal lobe attached to?

{{c1::It is attached superiorly to the inferior border of the hyoid bone by fibrous tissue. There are sometimes muscle fibres present in it named levator glandulae thyroidiae and are innervated by the external laryngeal nerve.}}

Where can accessory thyroid glands be found?

{{c1::
Near hyoid bone
In the tongue
In the superior mediastinum
Beneath sternocleidomastoid
}}
The superior thyroid artery is the {{c1::first::first/second/third}} branch from the anterior aspect of the external carotid.

After giving off its sternocleidomastoid and superior laryngeal branches, describe the course of the superior thyroid artery?

{{c1::
It pierces the pretracheal fascia as a single vessel, approaching the summit of the upper pole of thyroid with the external laryngeal nerve immediately behind it. 
The artery divides on the gland into an anterior branch that runs down to the isthmus and a posterior branch that runs down the back of the lobe and anastamoses with an ascending branch of the inferior thyroid artery from the lower pole.
}}

Where is the superior thyroid artery clipped in thyroidectomies and why?

{{c1::The superior thyroid artery is clipped right at the upper pole and not more proximally. This is because the nerve is immediately behind the artery as it approaches the upper pole, but further apart AT the pole.}}

The inferior thyroid artery originates from the {{c1::thyrocerviacal trunk::vessel}}. It arches upwards and medially behind the lower pole and divides {{c1::outside::inside/outside}} the pretracheal fascia into {{c2::four or five::how many}} branches.
The suspensory ligament always contains small branches of the {{c1::inferior::superior/inferior}} thyroid artery.
The non-recurrent variation of laryngeal nerve is more common on the {{c1::right::right/left}} side.

What is the thyroidea ima artery?

{{c1::It is a persistent embryonic vessel occuring in 3% of individuals, arising from brachiocephalic trunk/right common carotid artery/direct from arch of aorta and entering the lower part of the isthmus.}}
The venous return from the upper pole follows the superior thyroid artery. The superior thyroid vein enters either the {{c1::internal jugular}} or {{c1::facial vein}} in equal proportions.
The middle thyroid vein drains into {{c1::the internal juglular vein.}}

The inferior thyroid veins form a plexus that lies in the {{c1::pretracheal fascia::which plane}}. The plexus drains into the {{c1::brachiocephalic veins::which major vessel}}, most of it into the {{c1::left::right/left}} one.
Lymphatic drainage of the thyroid gland follows the thyroid {{c1::arteries::arteries/veins}}.

Describe the lymphatic drainage of the thyroid gland.

{{c1::
Upper pole -> anterosuperior group of deep cervical lymph nodes
Lower pole -> posteroinferior group behind carotid sheath

Few pass downwards into pretracheal nodes following course of thyroidea ima artery.
}}

There is actually more detail as seen here

But Last's is Last's.

What is the nerve supply of the thyroid gland?

{{c1::
- Sympathetic (vasoconstrictor) supply from middle cervical ganglion, entering the gland on the inferior thyroid artery. 
- Some fibres from superior cervical ganglion travel with superior thyroid artery. 
}}
Vagus nerve filaments traceable to gland but purpose unknown.
The thyroid is unique as it is the only endocrine gland to store its secretions {{c1::outside the cells::where}}.
The thyroid is a mass of {{c1::follicles}}, which have a single layer epithelial cell wall and contains {{c1::colloid}}.

Which part of the thyroid gland secretes calcitonin?

{{c1::C cells, or parafollicular cells constitute less than 2% of the epithelial cells. They are scattered on the outer aspects of the follicles and do not reach the lumina of the follicles.}}

The thyroid gland develops as a proliferation of cells from the causal end of the {{c1::thyroglossal duct::embryological structure}}. The parafollicular cells come from the {{c1::ultimobranchial body (Fifth pharyngeal pouch).::embryological structure}}
There are {{c2::four::how many}} parathyroid glands in {{c1::90}}% of subjects.

The superior parathyroid gland is more constant in position. It is usually on the back of the thyroid lobe, level with the {{c1::first::first/second/third}} tracheal ring and {{c1::above::above/below}} the inferior thyroid artery.

The inferior parathyroid gland is more variable in development. It is usually behind the lower pole, {{c1::below::above/below}} the inferior thyroid artery and {{c1::lateral::medial/lateral}} to the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

The parathyroids (especially inferior parathyroids) are sometimes embedded in thyroid tissue. What is a potential way to locate it?

{{c1::Follow the inferior thyroid artery upwards and downwards and a small branch should enter each gland.}}

What is the blood supply of the parathyroids?

{{c1::
Both upper and lower are supplied by the inferior thyroid artery
Minute veins join thyroid vessels
}}

Histologically, the parathyroid gland is a mass of small closely-packed {{c1::chief or principal}} cells which secrete {{c1::parathyroid hormone}}.

Two distinguising features on histological section is {{c1::homogeneity and vascularity}}.

The superior gland is often called parathyroid {{c1::IV::roman numeral}} as it develops from the {{c1::dorsal diverticulum}} of the {{c1::fourth::first/second/third/fourth}} pharyngeal pouch.
The inferior gand is called parathyroid {{c1::III::roman numeral}}, developed from the {{c1::third::first/second/third/fourth}} pouch but displaced caudally by the descent of the {{c1::thymus::organ}} from the same pouch.
The inferior parathyroid gland initially develops {{c1::above::below/above}} the superior parathyroid gland.
It therefore has further to migrate than the superior and is more liable to end up in unusual positions. About 10% of inferior glands are found within the capsule of the thymus.
For a parathyroidectomy, the thyroid is exposed then retracted {{c1::forward and medially::how}} so that the {{c1::posterior::which}} surfaces can be inspected for the parathyroids.
If all four parathyroid glands are to be removed, part of one of them is implanted into the {{c1::brachioradialis muscle of an arm.::where}}

It acts as an endocrine graft there. If later surgery is required, it is easier to approach an arm than the neck.


Note that this is Lasts 9th edition. Surgical practice can be wildly different now.
The trachea begins at the level of {{c1::C6::which}} vertebra.
Of the total length of the trachea of {{c1::10}}cm, {{c1::5}}cm are in the neck from cricoid cartilage to jugular notch. During deep inspiration the total length may increase to {{c1::15}}cm.
In the groove between the trachea and the oesophagus runs the {{c1::recurrent laryngeal}} nerve.

What vessels might be anterior to the cervical trachea?

{{c1::
Inferior thyroid veins
Anterior jugular venous arch
(If present) thyroidea ima artery
}}
As it passes downwards, the trachea also slopes {{c1::backwards::forwards/backwards}}.
While just below the skin at cricoid level, it is 2cm or more deep to the front of the jugular notch.
The trachea is approximately {{c1::2cm or more::centimetres}} deep to the front of the jugular notch.
For elective tracheostomy, a {{c1::transverse::transverse/longitudinal}} skin incision is made {{c1::2}}cm below the cricoid cartilage.
Some surgeons prefer longitudinal as you're staying more to the midline and avoiding any important structures. Lasts says transverse.

Tracheotomy implies {{c1::making an incision in the trachea}}. Tracheostomy involves {{c1::removing a small part of the wall (making a stoma)}}, but the strict distinction between these terms is often ignored.
The oesophagus commences in continuity with the cricopharyngeus muscle at the level of {{c1::the lower border of the cricoid cartialge (C6 vertebra)}}.

The oesophagus' inner circular layer is continuous from the {{c1::lower border of the cricopharyngeus}}. 
The outer longitudinal coat is attached to the {{c1::midline ridge of the lamina of the cricoid cartilage}} and to the {{c1::arytenoid cartilages}}. The fibres spiral down from this origin to the back of the oesophagus, whence the longitudinal coat is continuous.
Pus tracking laterally from around the pharynx passes {{c1::behind::in front of/behind}} the carotid sheath to point in the posterior triangle.
This is because the sheath is connected anteriorly by fibrous tissue to the fascia on the deep surface of the sternocleidomastoid but free posteriorly.

The 'dead space' around the internal jugular vein contains the {{c1::inferior deep cervical lymph}} nodes in anterior and posterior groups. The latter extends behind the sternocleidomastoid into the posterior triangle and forms the {{c1::supraclavicular}} group.

On the left side, the common carotid artery arises from the arch of the aorta and lies {{c1::in front of::medial to/in front of/behind}} the subclavian artery up to the sternoclavicular joint, where they diverge.
The brachiocephalic trunk bifurcates behind {{c1::the sternoclavicular joint::landmark}} into common carotid and subclavian arteries.
The surface marking of the common carotid artery is along a line from {{c1::the sternoclavicular joint}} to {{c1::its bifurcation near the greater horn of the hyoid bone}}.

How is the carotid pulse felt? What are you effectively doing by performing this manoeuvre?

{{c1::The carotid pulse can be felt by pressing backwards between the trachea and lower larynx medially and sternocleidomastoid laterally. This presses the artery against the tubercle of the transverse process of C6 vertebra.}}

Describe the formation of the ansa cervicalis.

{{c1::
The superior root (descendens hypoglossi) is a branch of the hypoglossal nerve given off where the nerve loops just below the posterior belly of digastric. It contains only C1 fibrse and runs down on the front of the IJV.

The inferior root (descendens cervicalis) is formed by the union of a branch each from C2 and C3 anterior rami in the cervical plexus. The single nerve formed spirals behind the internal jugular vein and runs down to join the superior root at a variable level.
}}

The labelling is somewhat erroneous as the descendens hypoglossi only commences after it branches off the hypoglossal nerve. The label for 'Superior Root AC' is actually pointing here at C1 ventral ramus.

Describe the path of the hypoglossal nerve from its emergence in the submandibular region.

{{c1::
In the submandibular region, the hypoglossal nerve emerges between the internal carotid artery and internal jugular vein deep to the posterior belly of the digastric. Hooking around the occipital artery it curves forwards over the external carotid and loop of the lingual artery.

As it crosses these three arteries, it lies just below the digastric, behind its tendon just above the tip of the greater horn of the hyoid bone. Here it gives off the superior root of the ansa cervicalis.

It continues forwards on the surface of the hyoglossus which separates it from the lingual artery, giving the branch to thyrohyoid (C1 fibres) then running deep to mylohyoid to enter the mouth.
}}
